articles.headline: More Than Pushing Cookies
articles.snippet: Selling Thin Mints and Samoas has brought Mary Ruiz self-esteem, money skills, a sense of accomplishment and some great electronic gear. Not bad for a 10-year-old.
articles.abstract: Selling Thin Mints and Samoas has brought Mary Ruiz self-esteem, money skills, a sense of accomplishment and some great electronic gear. Not bad for a 10-year-old.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — When you buy a box of Girl Scout cookies and devour 10 in a single sitting, as untold numbers of people will in the next month, you are propping up a pretty sizable enterprise.

articles.headline: Following a Herd of Bulls on Apple
articles.snippet: Even with reforms meant to reduce conflicts of interest, many analysts failed to foresee a plunge in Apple’s shares.
articles.abstract: Even with reforms meant to reduce conflicts of interest, many analysts failed to foresee a plunge in Apple’s shares.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last September, Apple shares hit a record $705. And to the overwhelming majority of Wall Street analysts, that meant one thing: buy.

articles.headline: Southeastern Asset Management to Fight Dell’s Takeover
articles.snippet: In a filing, Dell’s largest outside investor argues that the management-led buyout is too low and essentially robs shareholders. It is threatening to wage a campaign to kill the $24 billion deal.
articles.abstract: In a filing, Dell’s largest outside investor argues that the management-led buyout is too low and essentially robs shareholders. It is threatening to wage a campaign to kill the $24 billion deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: 7:44 p.m. | Updated One of the biggest investors in Dell said on Friday that it would oppose the company’s plans to go private, setting up a major potential roadblock for the biggest buyout since the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A Growing App Lets You See It, Then You Don’t
articles.snippet: The photos and messages sent through an app called Snapchat vanish in seconds. And that disappearing act has made the tiny start-up a technology hit.
articles.abstract: The photos and messages sent through an app called Snapchat vanish in seconds. And that disappearing act has made the tiny start-up a technology hit.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The ephemeral now has value, at least for users of cellphones.

articles.headline: Debating a Court to Vet Drone Strikes
articles.snippet: Some want to apply the model of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act court, which reviews eavesdropping on American soil, to the targeted killings of terrorism suspects.
articles.abstract: Some want to apply the model of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act court, which reviews eavesdropping on American soil, to the targeted killings of terrorism suspects.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since 1978, a secret court in Washington has approved national security eavesdropping on American soil — operations that for decades had been conducted based on presidential authority alone.

articles.headline: A Faceless Teenage Refugee Who Helped Ignite Syria’s War
articles.snippet: A young man from Dara’a, Syria, carries a burden — maybe an honor, too: He knows that he and his friends helped start an uprising.
articles.abstract: A young man from Dara’a, Syria, carries a burden — maybe an honor, too: He knows that he and his friends helped start an uprising.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — In a listless border town, the teenager goes unnoticed, one of the hundreds of thousands of refugees who have fled the Syrian civil war, dashing across villages and farms to land in Jordan, just five miles from home.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: John E. Karlin, Who Led the Way to All-Digit Dialing, Dies at 94
articles.snippet: Mr. Karlin, a Bell Labs industrial research psychologist, was also instrumental in the shortening of telephone cords and the creation of rectangular keypads for touch-tone models.
articles.abstract: Mr. Karlin, a Bell Labs industrial research psychologist, was also instrumental in the shortening of telephone cords and the creation of rectangular keypads for touch-tone models.
articles.lead_paragraph: A generation ago, when the poetry of PEnnsylvania and BUtterfield was about to give way to telephone numbers in unpoetic strings, a critical question arose: Would people be able to remember all seven digits long enough to dial them?

articles.headline: On the Waiting List at the Debt-Rating Club
articles.snippet: Legislators have tried to open the world of credit-ratings agencies to more competition. But for one small firm, it’s been tough to gain federal recognition.
articles.abstract: Legislators have tried to open the world of credit-ratings agencies to more competition. But for one small firm, it’s been tough to gain federal recognition.
articles.lead_paragraph: BETTER late than never.

articles.headline: Battling College Costs, a Paycheck at a Time
articles.snippet: The modern realities of soaring tuition and other expenses are testing, but not defeating, the tradition of working one’s way through school.
articles.abstract: The modern realities of soaring tuition and other expenses are testing, but not defeating, the tradition of working one’s way through school.
articles.lead_paragraph: If Steve Boedefeld graduates from Appalachian State University without any student loan debt, it will be because of the money he earned fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan and the money he now saves by eating what he grows or kills.

articles.headline: Giffords Eases Steadily Into New Life, and Cause
articles.snippet: Gabrielle Giffords, the former Democratic congresswoman from Arizona, is settling into the third act of her public life as she shifts to dedicate her career to reducing gun violence.
articles.abstract: Gabrielle Giffords, the former Democratic congresswoman from Arizona, is settling into the third act of her public life as she shifts to dedicate her career to reducing gun violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — Gabrielle Giffords looked slightly stricken as she considered the question: Would she feel bad about starring in a political advertisement against her former House colleagues who declined to stand with her on guns? “Yes,” she said, it would be painful.

articles.headline: At Boys’ Home, Seeking Graves, and the Reason
articles.snippet: A Florida home for wayward boys was once synonymous with horrific conditions. Now, some are trying to discern what occurred by digging for bodies on the campus’s grounds.
articles.abstract: A Florida home for wayward boys was once synonymous with horrific conditions. Now, some are trying to discern what occurred by digging for bodies on the campus’s grounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARIANNA, Fla. — Nobody is quite sure how many boys’ bodies lie beneath the grounds of the notorious Arthur G. Dozier School for Boys, or which one is Thomas or Owen or Robert.

articles.headline: Obama’s Turn in Bush’s Bind
articles.snippet: A onetime critic of his predecessor, President Obama finds himself justifying muscular defense policies while detractors complain that he has sacrificed core values.
articles.abstract: A onetime critic of his predecessor, President Obama finds himself justifying muscular defense policies while detractors complain that he has sacrificed core values.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If President Obama tuned in to the past week’s bracing debate on Capitol Hill about terrorism, executive power, secrecy and due process, he might have recognized the arguments his critics were making: He once made some of them himself.

articles.headline: Mali War Shifts as Rebels Hide in High Sahara
articles.snippet: Expelling the Islamist militants may have been the easy part of retaking Malian towns. Now French forces are focusing on a harsh mountain range where many of those militants are hiding.
articles.abstract: Expelling the Islamist militants may have been the easy part of retaking Malian towns. Now French forces are focusing on a harsh mountain range where many of those militants are hiding.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Just as Al Qaeda once sought refuge in the mountains of Tora Bora, the Islamist militants now on the run in Mali are hiding out in their own forbidding landscape, a rugged, rocky expanse in northeastern Mali that has become a symbol of the continued challenges facing the international effort to stabilize the Sahara.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Peter Tinti

articles.headline: Disruptions: Where Apple and Dick Tracy May Converge
articles.snippet: Though such a device has been lost to science fiction comics and spy movies of a pre-smartphone era, the smart watch might soon become a reality, in the form of a curved glass device made by Apple.
articles.abstract: Though such a device has been lost to science fiction comics and spy movies of a pre-smartphone era, the smart watch might soon become a reality, in the form of a curved glass device made by Apple.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dick Tracy had one. As did Inspector Gadget and James Bond. A watch that doubled as a computer, two-way radio, mapping device or television.

articles.headline: American and US Airways May Announce a Merger This Week
articles.snippet: The match would create the nation’s biggest airline and concentrate even further a once-fragmented industry.
articles.abstract: The match would create the nation’s biggest airline and concentrate even further a once-fragmented industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of negotiations, American Airlines and US Airways appeared likely to announce a merger this week, which would create the nation’s biggest airline and concentrate even further a once-fragmented industry.

articles.headline: Damascus on Edge as War Seeps Into Syrian Capital
articles.snippet: For months, Damascus has hunched in a defensive crouch as fighting raged in suburbs, but a rebel advance has created a new level of alarm and disorder.
articles.abstract: For months, Damascus has hunched in a defensive crouch as fighting raged in suburbs, but a rebel advance has created a new level of alarm and disorder.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — Unkempt government soldiers, some appearing drunk, have been deployed near a rebel-held railway station in the southern reaches of this tense capital. Office workers on 29th of May Street, in the heart of the city, tell of huddling at their desks, trapped inside for hours by gun battles that sound alarmingly close.
articles.byline: By An employee of The New York Times in Damascus, Syria and Anne Barnard

articles.headline: Samsung Emerges as a Potent Rival to Apple’s Cool
articles.snippet: After sweeping the market with the iPhone and the iPad, Apple has only one real competitor. And Samsung, unlike Apple, does think people know what they want.
articles.abstract: After sweeping the market with the iPhone and the iPad, Apple has only one real competitor. And Samsung, unlike Apple, does think people know what they want.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple, for the first time in years, is hearing footsteps.

articles.headline: Young, Liberal and Open to Big Government
articles.snippet: In a trend that is surprising pollsters and jangling the nerves of Republicans, a majority of young people embraces President Obama’s notion that government can be a constructive force.
articles.abstract: In a trend that is surprising pollsters and jangling the nerves of Republicans, a majority of young people embraces President Obama’s notion that government can be a constructive force.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISSOULA, Mont. — This funky college town, nestled along two rivers where five mountain ranges converge, has long been a liberal pocket, an isolated speck of blue in a deeply red state. Now Montana is electing more politicians who lean that way, thanks to a different-minded generation of young voters animated by the recession and social issues.

articles.headline: Debating Drones, in the Open
articles.snippet: Perhaps the reason so many people are in the dark about deadly drone strikes is because they want to be.
articles.abstract: Perhaps the reason so many people are in the dark about deadly drone strikes is because they want to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, the debate over drone strikes broke out into plain view during the confirmation hearings for John O. Brennan, President Obama’s choice to head the Central Intelligence Agency. Given that the program has been operating largely under the public radar, a question has been raised whether the news media have done their job in keeping the American public informed about this radically different approach to warfare.

articles.headline: Obama to Renew Drive for Cuts in Nuclear Arms
articles.snippet: White House officials are looking at a cut that would take the arsenal of deployed weapons to just above 1,000, compared with the current 1,700.
articles.abstract: White House officials are looking at a cut that would take the arsenal of deployed weapons to just above 1,000, compared with the current 1,700.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will use his State of the Union speech on Tuesday to reinvigorate one of his signature national security objectives — drastically reducing nuclear arsenals around the world — after securing agreement in recent months with the United States military that the American nuclear force can be cut in size by roughly a third.

articles.headline: Speculative Bets Prove Risky as Savers Chase Payoff
articles.snippet: Brokers used to promote bad investments mainly to people trying to get rich quick, but with traditional portfolios losing value, more ordinary retirement savers are being duped.
articles.abstract: Brokers used to promote bad investments mainly to people trying to get rich quick, but with traditional portfolios losing value, more ordinary retirement savers are being duped.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators across the country are confronting a wave of investor fraud that is saddling retirement savers with steep losses on complex products that until a few years ago were pitched only to the most sophisticated investors.

articles.headline: Menendez Backed Donor on Port Security Plan
articles.snippet: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey discouraged any government gift of port security equipment to the Dominican Republic, citing concern for a company run by his friend, a major campaign contributor.
articles.abstract: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey discouraged any government gift of port security equipment to the Dominican Republic, citing concern for a company run by his friend, a major campaign contributor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Robert Menendez sought to discourage any plan by the United States government to donate port security equipment to the Dominican Republic, citing concern that the advanced screening gear might undermine efforts by a private company — run by a major campaign contributor and friend of his — to do the work.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and William K. Rashbaum

articles.headline: S.E.C.’s Revolving Door Hurts Its Effectiveness, Report Says
articles.snippet: A watchdog group’s study pointed to cases where companies hired former agency employees to wage successful fights against the commission’s enforcement and policy efforts.
articles.abstract: A watchdog group’s study pointed to cases where companies hired former agency employees to wage successful fights against the commission’s enforcement and policy efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert S. Khuzami took a step through Washington’s revolving door on Friday, departing his post as one of Wall Street’s top enforcers en route to the private sector, where he is expected to reap millions.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: A CBS Deal Bolsters Amazon’s Challenge to Netflix
articles.snippet: Slowly but confidently, Amazon is building a library of television shows and movies to rival that of Netflix, much to the satisfaction of media companies like Time Warner and CBS, whose executives love to see the competition.
articles.abstract: Slowly but confidently, Amazon is building a library of television shows and movies to rival that of Netflix, much to the satisfaction of media companies like Time Warner and CBS, whose executives love to see the competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Slowly but confidently, Amazon is building a library of television shows and movies to rival that of Netflix, much to the satisfaction of media companies like Time Warner and CBS, whose executives love to see the competition.
